questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question: The tenth percentile corresponds to observations in bin(s):
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The tenth percentile corresponds to the lowest 10 percent of the observations in the sample, which are in bins 1 and 2.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The tenth percentile corresponds to the lowest 10 percent of the observations in the sample, which are in bins 1 and 2.

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
A portfolio manager would like to calculate the compound rate of return on an investment. Which of the following mean returns will he most likely use?

  1. Geometric
  2. Harmonic
  3. Arithmetic
questions.explanation: Solution Correct . The geometric mean return represents the growth rate or compound rate of return on an investment. Incorrect. The harmonic mean may be viewed as a special type of weighted mean in which an observationâ€™s weight is inversely proportional to its magnitude. The harmonic mean is a relatively specialized concept of the mean that is appropriate when averaging ratios (â€œamount per unitâ€) when the ratios are repeatedly applied to a fixed quantity to yield a variable number of units. Incorrect. The arithmetic mean return reflects the average of the single-periods performance. Statistical Measures of Asset Returns calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of central tendency and location to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. The geometric mean return represents the growth rate or compound rate of return on an investment.

  2. Incorrect. The harmonic mean may be viewed as a special type of weighted mean in which an observationâ€™s weight is inversely proportional to its magnitude. The harmonic mean is a relatively specialized concept of the mean that is appropriate when averaging ratios (â€œamount per unitâ€) when the ratios are repeatedly applied to a fixed quantity to yield a variable number of units.

  3. Incorrect. The arithmetic mean return reflects the average of the single-periods performance.

Statistical Measures of Asset Returns

  • calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of central tendency and location to address an investment problem

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question: The second quintile corresponds to observations in bin(s):
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The second quintile corresponds to the second 20 percent of observations. The first 20 percent consists of bins 1 through 4. The second 20 percent of observations consists of bins 5 through 8.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The second quintile corresponds to the second 20 percent of observations. The first 20 percent consists of bins 1 through 4. The second 20 percent of observations consists of bins 5 through 8.

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
Which of the following statements is most accurate? The first quintile generally exceeds the:

  1. first quartile.
  2. median.
  3. first decile.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. The first quintile is the 20th percentile. The first decile is the 10th percentile, the first quartile is the 25th percentile, and the median is the 50th percentile. Incorrect. The first quintile is the 20th percentile. The first decile is the 10th percentile, the first quartile is the 25th percentile, and the median is the 50th percentile. Correct . The first quintile is the 20th percentile (a percentile indicates the value below which a given percentage of observations in a group fall). The first decile is the 10th percentile, the first quartile is the 25th percentile, and the median is the 50th percentile. Although it is possible that these various percentiles or some subsets of them might be equal (for example, the 10th percentile possibly could be equal to the 20th percentile), in general, the order from smallest to largest would be: first decile, first quintile, first quartile, median. Statistical Measures of Asset Returns calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of central tendency and location to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. The first quintile is the 20th percentile. The first decile is the 10th percentile, the first quartile is the 25th percentile, and the median is the 50th percentile.

  2. Incorrect. The first quintile is the 20th percentile. The first decile is the 10th percentile, the first quartile is the 25th percentile, and the median is the 50th percentile.

  3. Correct. The first quintile is the 20th percentile (a percentile indicates the value below which a given percentage of observations in a group fall). The first decile is the 10th percentile, the first quartile is the 25th percentile, and the median is the 50th percentile. Although it is possible that these various percentiles or some subsets of them might be equal (for example, the 10th percentile possibly could be equal to the 20th percentile), in general, the order from smallest to largest would be: first decile, first quintile, first quartile, median.

Statistical Measures of Asset Returns

  • calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of central tendency and location to address an investment problem

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
The following table shows the volatility of a series of funds that belong to the same peer group, ranked in ascending order:

Fund Volatility (%)
Fund 1 9.81
Fund 2 10.12
Fund 3 10.84
Fund 4 11.33
Fund 5 12.25
Fund 6 13.39
Fund 7 13.42
Fund 8 13.99
Fund 9 14.47
Fund 10 14.85
Fund 11 15.00
Fund 12 17.36
Fund 13 17.98

The approximate value of the first quintile is closest to:

  1. 10.70%.
  2. 11.09%.
  3. 10.84%.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct . The position of the first quintile is found with the following formula: L y = ( n + 1) Ã— ( y /100),where y = the percentage point at which the distribution is divided. In this case, y = 20, which corresponds to the 20th percentile (first quintile) n = the number of observations (funds) in the peer group. In this case, n = 13 L 20 = the location of the 20th percentile (first quintile) L 20 = (13 + 1) Ã— (20/100) = 2.80. Therefore, the location of the first quintile is between the volatility of Fund 2 and Fund 3 (because they are ranked in ascending order). Linear interpolation is used to find the approximate value of the first quintile: P 20 â‰ˆ X 2 + (2.80 âˆ’ 2) Ã— ( X 3 âˆ’ X 2 ) where X 2 = the volatility of Fund 2 X 3 = the volatility of Fund 3 P 20 = the approximate value of the first quintile P 20 â‰ˆ 10.12% + (2.80 âˆ’ 2) Ã— (10.84% âˆ’ 10.12%) = 10.70% Incorrect. It is the approximate value of the first quartile . The position of the first quartile is found as follows: L 25 = (13 + 1) Ã— (25/100) = 3.50. So, the location of the first quartile is between the volatility of Fund 3 and Fund 4. Linear interpolation is used to find the approximate value of the first quartile: P 25 â‰ˆ X 3 + (3.50 âˆ’ 3) Ã— ( X 4 âˆ’ X 3 ) P 25 â‰ˆ 10.84% + (3.50 âˆ’ 3) Ã— (11.33% âˆ’ 10.84%) = 11.09% Incorrect. The position of the first quintile is found with the following formula: L y = ( n + 1) Ã— ( y /100) L 20 = (13 + 1) Ã— (20/100) = 2.80. 2.80 is then rounded up to 3 and the volatility of Fund 3 is taken. That corresponds to 10.84%. Statistical Measures of Asset Returns calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of central tendency and location to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. The position of the first quintile is found with the following formula:

    Ly = (n + 1) Ã— (y/100),where

    y = the percentage point at which the distribution is divided. In this case, y = 20, which corresponds to the 20th percentile (first quintile)

    n = the number of observations (funds) in the peer group. In this case, n = 13

    L20 = the location of the 20th percentile (first quintile)

    L20 = (13 + 1) Ã— (20/100) = 2.80.

    Therefore, the location of the first quintile is between the volatility of Fund 2 and Fund 3 (because they are ranked in ascending order).

    Linear interpolation is used to find the approximate value of the first quintile:

    P20 â‰ˆ X2 + (2.80 âˆ’ 2) Ã— (X3 âˆ’ X2) where

    X2 = the volatility of Fund 2

    X3 = the volatility of Fund 3

    P20 = the approximate value of the first quintile

    P20 â‰ˆ 10.12% + (2.80 âˆ’ 2) Ã— (10.84% âˆ’ 10.12%) = 10.70%

  2. Incorrect. It is the approximate value of the first quartile. The position of the first quartile is found as follows: L25 = (13 + 1) Ã— (25/100) = 3.50. So, the location of the first quartile is between the volatility of Fund 3 and Fund 4. Linear interpolation is used to find the approximate value of the first quartile:

    P25 â‰ˆ X3 + (3.50 âˆ’ 3) Ã— (X4 âˆ’ X3)

    P25 â‰ˆ 10.84% + (3.50 âˆ’ 3) Ã— (11.33% âˆ’ 10.84%) = 11.09%

  3. Incorrect. The position of the first quintile is found with the following formula:

    Ly = (n + 1) Ã— (y/100)

    L20 = (13 + 1) Ã— (20/100) = 2.80. 2.80 is then rounded up to 3 and the volatility of Fund 3 is taken. That corresponds to 10.84%.

Statistical Measures of Asset Returns

  • calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of central tendency and location to address an investment problem

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question: The interquartile range is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. The interquartile range is the difference between the lowest value in the second quartile and the highest value in the third quartile. The lowest value of the second quartile is 34.72, and the highest value of the third quartile is 58.34. Therefore, the interquartile range is 58.34 âˆ’ 34.72 = 23.62.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. The interquartile range is the difference between the lowest value in the second quartile and the highest value in the third quartile. The lowest value of the second quartile is 34.72, and the highest value of the third quartile is 58.34. Therefore, the interquartile range is 58.34 âˆ’ 34.72 = 23.62.

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
A risk manager would like to calculate the coefficient of variation of a portfolio. The following table reports the annual returns of the portfolio and of the risk-free rate over the most recent five years:

Year Portfolio Return Risk-Free Rate
1 4.0% 2.0%
2 â€“1.0% 1.5%
3 7.0% 1.0%
4 11.0% 1.0%
5 2.0% 0.5%

The coefficient of variation of the portfolio is closest to:

  1. 0.74.
  2. 0.90.
  3. 1.00.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. It is the Sharpe ratio, not the coefficient of variation. First calculate the mean annual risk-free return over the five years: ğ‘… â¯ â¯ â¯ ğ¹ = 2.0 % + 1.5 % + 1.0 % + 1.0 % + 0.5 % 5 R Â¯ F = 2.0 % + 1.5 % + 1.0 % + 1.0 % + 0.5 % 5 = 1.2% Then calculate the Sharpe ratio with the following formula: S h = ğ‘… â¯ â¯ â¯ ğ‘ âˆ’ ğ‘… â¯ â¯ â¯ ğ¹ ğ‘  ğ‘ = 4.6 % âˆ’ 1.2 % 4.62 % R Â¯ p âˆ’ R Â¯ F s p = 4.6 % âˆ’ 1.2 % 4.62 % = 0.74 Incorrect. In the formula for the standard deviation, it uses n instead of â€œ n âˆ’ 1â€ in the denominator: s = 0.00004 + 0.00314 + 0.00058 + 0.00410 + 0.00068 5 â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ âˆš 0.00004 + 0.00314 + 0.00058 + 0.00410 + 0.00068 5 = 4.13% Then, calculate the CV: CV = 4.13 % 4.6 % 4.13 % 4.6 % = 0.90 Correct . First calculate the sample mean return as follows: ğ‘‹ â¯ â¯ â¯ = âˆ‘ ğ‘– = 1 ğ‘› ğ‘‹ ğ‘– ğ‘› X Â¯ = âˆ‘ i = 1 n X i n where n = the number of observations in the sample i = the index for the year X i = is the return in year i ğ‘‹ â¯ â¯ â¯ = ( 4.0 % âˆ’ 1.0 % + 7.0 % + 11.0 % + 2.0 % ) 5 = 23.0 % 5 = 4.6 % X Â¯ = ( 4.0 % âˆ’ 1.0 % + 7.0 % + 11.0 % + 2.0 % ) 5 = 23.0 % 5 = 4.6 % Then calculate the sample standard deviation with the following formula: ğ‘  = âˆ‘ ğ‘– = 1 ğ‘› ( ğ‘‹ ğ‘– âˆ’ ğ‘‹ â¯ â¯ â¯ â¯ ) 2 ğ‘› âˆ’ 1 â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ î€ â· î€€ î€€ s = âˆ‘ i = 1 n ( X i âˆ’ X Â¯ ) 2 n âˆ’ 1 Year ( ğ‘‹ ğ‘– âˆ’ ğ‘‹ â¯ â¯ â¯ ) 2 ( X i âˆ’ X Â¯ ) 2 1 (4.0% âˆ’ 4.6%) 2 = 0.00004 2 (âˆ’1.0% âˆ’ 4.6%) 2 = 0.00314 3 (7.0% âˆ’ 4.6%) 2 = 0.00058 4 (11.0% âˆ’ 4.6%) 2 = 0.00410 5 (2.0% âˆ’ 4.6%) 2 = 0.00068 s = 0.00004 + 0.00314 + 0.00058 + 0.00410 + 0.00068 5 âˆ’ 1 â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ â€¾ âˆš 0.00004 + 0.00314 + 0.00058 + 0.00410 + 0.00068 5 âˆ’ 1 = 4.62% The coefficient of variation (CV) is calculated with the following formula: CV = ğ‘  ğ‘‹ â¯ â¯ â¯ â¯ = 4.62 % 4.6 % s X Â¯ = 4.62 % 4.6 % = 1.0 Statistical Measures of Asset Returns calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of dispersion to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. It is the Sharpe ratio, not the coefficient of variation. First calculate the mean annual risk-free return over the five years:

    ğ‘…â¯â¯â¯ğ¹=2.0%+1.5%+1.0%+1.0%+0.5%5RÂ¯F=2.0%+1.5%+1.0%+1.0%+0.5%5 = 1.2%

  2. Incorrect. In the formula for the standard deviation, it uses n instead of â€œn âˆ’ 1â€ in the denominator:

    Then, calculate the CV:

    CV = 4.13%4.6%4.13%4.6% = 0.90

  3. Correct. First calculate the sample mean return as follows:ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯=âˆ‘ğ‘–=1ğ‘›ğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘›XÂ¯=âˆ‘i=1nXin where

    n = the number of observations in the sample

    i = the index for the year

    Xi = is the return in year i

    ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯=(4.0%âˆ’1.0%+7.0%+11.0%+2.0%)5=23.0%5=4.6%XÂ¯=(4.0%âˆ’1.0%+7.0%+11.0%+2.0%)5=23.0%5=4.6%

    Then calculate the sample standard deviation with the following formula:

    ğ‘ =âˆ‘ğ‘–=1ğ‘›(ğ‘‹ğ‘–âˆ’ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯â¯)2ğ‘›âˆ’1â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾î€â·î€€î€€s=âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯)2nâˆ’1

    Year (ğ‘‹ğ‘–âˆ’ğ‘‹â¯â¯â¯)2(Xiâˆ’XÂ¯)2
    1 (4.0% âˆ’ 4.6%)2 = 0.00004
    2 (âˆ’1.0% âˆ’ 4.6%)2 = 0.00314
    3 (7.0% âˆ’ 4.6%)2 = 0.00058
    4 (11.0% âˆ’ 4.6%)2 = 0.00410
    5 (2.0% âˆ’ 4.6%)2 = 0.00068

    s = 0.00004+0.00314+0.00058+0.00410+0.000685âˆ’1â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾â€¾âˆš0.00004+0.00314+0.00058+0.00410+0.000685âˆ’1 = 4.62%

    The coefficient of variation (CV) is calculated with the following formula:

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
For a set of return observations, the coefficient of variation is best described as a measure of:

  1. risk per unit of mean return.
  2. mean excess return earned per unit of risk.
  3. average absolute deviation around the mean return.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because when the observations are returns, the coefficient of variation measures the amount of risk (standard deviation) per unit of mean return. Incorrect because it describes the Sharpe ratio, not the coefficient of variation. The Sharpe ratio measures the reward, in terms of mean excess return, per unit of risk, where mean excess return is defined as the average rate of return in excess of the risk-free rate. Incorrect because it describes the mean absolute deviation (MAD), not the coefficient of variation. The MAD is defined as the mean of the absolute values of deviations from the sample mean. Statistical Measures of Asset Returns calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of dispersion to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct because when the observations are returns, the coefficient of variation measures the amount of risk (standard deviation) per unit of mean return.

  2. Incorrect because it describes the Sharpe ratio, not the coefficient of variation. The Sharpe ratio measures the reward, in terms of mean excess return, per unit of risk, where mean excess return is defined as the average rate of return in excess of the risk-free rate.

  3. Incorrect because it describes the mean absolute deviation (MAD), not the coefficient of variation. The MAD is defined as the mean of the absolute values of deviations from the sample mean.

Statistical Measures of Asset Returns

  • calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of dispersion to address an investment problem

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
Exhibit 12 shows the annual MSCI World Index total returns for a 10-year period.

Exhibit 1:

MSCI World Index Returns

Year 1 15.25% Year 6 30.79%
Year 2 10.02% Year 7 12.34%
Year 3 20.65% Year 8 âˆ’5.02%
Year 4 9.57% Year 9 16.54%
Year 5 âˆ’40.33% Year 10 27.37%

The fourth quintile return for the MSCI World Index is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Quintiles divide a distribution into fifths, with the fourth quintile occurring at the point at which 80 percent of the observations lie below it. The fourth quintile is equivalent to the 80th percentile,Â which includes 8th (20.65%) highest value. The value closest to the fourth quintile return is 20.65%.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Quintiles divide a distribution into fifths, with the fourth quintile occurring at the point at which 80 percent of the observations lie below it. The fourth quintile is equivalent to the 80th percentile,Â which includes 8th (20.65%) highest value. The value closest to the fourth quintile return is 20.65%.

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
An analyst gathers the following information about a portfolio's returns:

Year Return
1 6%
2 7%
3 3%
4 2%
5 4%

If the target return is 5%, the target downside deviation is closest to:

  1. 1.7%.
  2. 1.9%.
  3. 2.2%.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because n (5) is used in the calculation instead of n â€“ 1: (14/5) 0.5 , resulting in 1.67% â‰ˆ 1.7%. Correct because the formula for target downside deviation is [Î£( X i â€“ B ) 2 /( n â€“ 1)] 0.5 , where X i is the return for the period, B is the target return and n is the total number of sample observations. Moreover, the summation is taken over only those observations ( X i ) that are less than or equal to the target B . Year Return (%) Deviations from the target Squared deviations 1 6 0 0 2 7 0 0 3 3 â€“2 4 4 2 â€“3 9 5 4 â€“1 1 Since the sum of squared deviations is 14, the target downside deviation = [14/(5 â€“ 1)] 0.5 , resulting in 1.87% â‰ˆ 1.9%. Incorrect because all the returns are used in the calculation, not just the returns below the target. In other words, the standard deviation from the target return is calculated. Since the sum of all squared deviations is 14 + 5 = 19, the target downside deviation is calculated as: [19/(5 â€“ 1)] 0.5 , resulting in 2.18% â‰ˆ 2.2%. This answer is also closest if n is assumed to be the number of observations used in the correct calculation (3): (14/3) 0.5 , resulting in 2.16% â‰ˆ 2.2%. Statistical Measures of Asset Returns calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of dispersion to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because n (5) is used in the calculation instead of n â€“ 1: (14/5)0.5, resulting in 1.67% â‰ˆ 1.7%.

  2. Correct because the formula for target downside deviation is [Î£(Xi â€“ B)2/(n â€“ 1)]0.5, where Xi is the return for the period, B is the target return and n is the total number of sample observations. Moreover, the summation is taken over only those observations (Xi) that are less than or equal to the target B.

    Year Return (%) Deviations from the target Squared deviations
    1 6 0 0
    2 7 0 0
    3 3 â€“2 4
    4 2 â€“3 9
    5 4 â€“1 1

    Since the sum of squared deviations is 14, the target downside deviation = [14/(5 â€“ 1)]0.5, resulting in 1.87% â‰ˆ 1.9%.

  3. Incorrect because all the returns are used in the calculation, not just the returns below the target. In other words, the standard deviation from the target return is calculated. Since the sum of all squared deviations is 14 + 5 = 19, the target downside deviation is calculated as: [19/(5 â€“ 1)]0.5, resulting in 2.18% â‰ˆ 2.2%.

    This answer is also closest if n is assumed to be the number of observations used in the correct calculation (3): (14/3)0.5, resulting in 2.16% â‰ˆ 2.2%.

Statistical Measures of Asset Returns

  • calculate, interpret, and evaluate measures of dispersion to address an investment problem

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
For a positively skewed unimodal distribution, which of the following measures is most accurately described as the largest?

  1. Median
  2. Mean
  3. Mode
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. For the positively skewed unimodal distribution, the mode is less than the median, which is less than the mean. Correct . For a positively skewed unimodal distribution, the mode is less than the median, which is less than the mean. Incorrect. For the positively skewed unimodal distribution, the mode is less than the median, which is less than the mean. Statistical Measures of Asset Returns interpret and evaluate measures of skewness and kurtosis to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. For the positively skewed unimodal distribution, the mode is less than the median, which is less than the mean.

  2. Correct. For a positively skewed unimodal distribution, the mode is less than the median, which is less than the mean.

  3. Incorrect. For the positively skewed unimodal distribution, the mode is less than the median, which is less than the mean.

Statistical Measures of Asset Returns

  • interpret and evaluate measures of skewness and kurtosis to address an investment problem

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
Equity return distributions are best described as being:

  1. leptokurtic.
  2. platykurtic.
  3. mesokurtic.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct . Most equity return distributions are best described as being leptokurtic (i.e., more peaked than normal). Incorrect. Most equity return series have been found to be leptokurtic. Incorrect. Most equity return series have been found to be leptokurtic. Statistical Measures of Asset Returns interpret and evaluate measures of skewness and kurtosis to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. Most equity return distributions are best described as being leptokurtic (i.e., more peaked than normal).

  2. Incorrect. Most equity return series have been found to be leptokurtic.

  3. Incorrect. Most equity return series have been found to be leptokurtic.

Statistical Measures of Asset Returns

  • interpret and evaluate measures of skewness and kurtosis to address an investment problem

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
The figure below shows the histogram for the distribution of weekly returns on an index.

The median of the returns on the index, if compared to the mean, will most likely be:

  1. smaller.
  2. equal.
  3. greater.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. The histogram clearly shows that the return distribution of the index is positively skewed (skewed to the right) and is unimodal (it has one most frequently occurring value). For a positively skewed unimodal distribution, the median is always less than the mean. Incorrect. By looking at the histogram, it is clear that the return distribution of the index is positively skewed (skewed to the right) and is unimodal (it has one most frequently occurring value). For a positively skewed unimodal distribution, the median is always less than the mean. Incorrect. By looking at the histogram, it is clear that the return distribution of the index is positively skewed (skewed to the right) and is unimodal (it has one most frequently occurring value). For a positively skewed unimodal distribution, the median is always less than the mean. Statistical Measures of Asset Returns interpret and evaluate measures of skewness and kurtosis to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. The histogram clearly shows that the return distribution of the index is positively skewed (skewed to the right) and is unimodal (it has one most frequently occurring value). For a positively skewed unimodal distribution, the median is always less than the mean.

  2. Incorrect. By looking at the histogram, it is clear that the return distribution of the index is positively skewed (skewed to the right) and is unimodal (it has one most frequently occurring value). For a positively skewed unimodal distribution, the median is always less than the mean.

  3. Incorrect. By looking at the histogram, it is clear that the return distribution of the index is positively skewed (skewed to the right) and is unimodal (it has one most frequently occurring value). For a positively skewed unimodal distribution, the median is always less than the mean.

Statistical Measures of Asset Returns

  • interpret and evaluate measures of skewness and kurtosis to address an investment problem

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
For a given expected return and standard deviation, investors are most likely to be attracted to return distributions that are:

  1. negatively skewed.
  2. positively skewed.
  3. normal.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Investors are most likely to be attracted to positively skewed return distributions. For a given expected return and standard deviation, investors are less likely to be attracted by a negative skew because the mean return lies below the median. Relative to the mean return, negative skew amounts to limited, though frequent, upside returns compared with somewhat unlimited, but less frequent, downside returns. Correct . For a given expected return and standard deviation, investors are most likely to be attracted by a positive skew because the mean return lies above the median. Relative to the mean return, positive skew amounts to limited, though frequent, downside returns compared with somewhat unlimited, but less frequent, upside returns. Incorrect. For a given expected return and standard deviation, investors are most likely to be attracted by a positive skew because the mean return lies above the median. Relative to the mean return, positive skew amounts to limited, though frequent, downside returns compared with somewhat unlimited, but less frequent, upside returns. In a normal distribution, median and mean are equal. Statistical Measures of Asset Returns interpret and evaluate measures of skewness and kurtosis to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Investors are most likely to be attracted to positively skewed return distributions. For a given expected return and standard deviation, investors are less likely to be attracted by a negative skew because the mean return lies below the median. Relative to the mean return, negative skew amounts to limited, though frequent, upside returns compared with somewhat unlimited, but less frequent, downside returns.

  2. Correct. For a given expected return and standard deviation, investors are most likely to be attracted by a positive skew because the mean return lies above the median. Relative to the mean return, positive skew amounts to limited, though frequent, downside returns compared with somewhat unlimited, but less frequent, upside returns.

  3. Incorrect. For a given expected return and standard deviation, investors are most likely to be attracted by a positive skew because the mean return lies above the median. Relative to the mean return, positive skew amounts to limited, though frequent, downside returns compared with somewhat unlimited, but less frequent, upside returns. In a normal distribution, median and mean are equal.

Statistical Measures of Asset Returns

  • interpret and evaluate measures of skewness and kurtosis to address an investment problem

questions.title: Statistical Measures of Asset Returns
questions.question:
A return distribution with negative skew and a mean of zero most likely has:

  1. frequent small gains and a few extreme losses.
  2. frequent small losses and a few extreme gains.
  3. frequent extreme losses and a few small gains.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because a return distribution with negative skew has frequent small gains and a few extreme losses. Incorrect because a return distribution with positive skew has frequent small losses and a few extreme gains. A return distribution with negative skew has frequent small gains and a few extreme losses. Incorrect because a return distribution with positive skew has frequent small losses and a few extreme gains. A return distribution with negative skew has frequent small gains and a few extreme losses. Statistical Measures of Asset Returns interpret and evaluate measures of skewness and kurtosis to address an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct because a return distribution with negative skew has frequent small gains and a few extreme losses.

  2. Incorrect because a return distribution with positive skew has frequent small losses and a few extreme gains. A return distribution with negative skew has frequent small gains and a few extreme losses.

  3. Incorrect because a return distribution with positive skew has frequent small losses and a few extreme gains. A return distribution with negative skew has frequent small gains and a few extreme losses.

Statistical Measures of Asset Returns

  • interpret and evaluate measures of skewness and kurtosis to address an investment problem
